captions.text: - I hate being cold.
Like I'm from the desert

and cold is just not
something that I'm into.

- I actually have kind of
like a achy, bruised knee,

and I'm really hoping that
it's gonna magically fix it.
- My biggest fear would be like my fingers
getting really cold, and like falling off.
- I went skydiving before.
I think I can do this.
(techno music)

- So basically, what you
guys are gonna be doing today

is you're going to be gonna
be going into a chamber.
It's negative 220 degrees.
Some risks associated with this

could be frostbite, skin
burns and irritations,

but, we don't let you
go in for long enough
for that even to happen,

so we're gonna put you in
for a safe amount of time.
It's a minute-and-a-half.

A minute-and-a-half sounds
like a very short time,

but it'll be the longest
minute-and-a-half of your life.

- I honestly feel like I'm
in line for a roller coaster.
- Ready.
- Oh, she's ready.
- Well, I'm getting naked for a video.
- Just another day at work.
What if I pee my pants while I'm in there?
- I was literally just thinking that!
(dramatic music)

(screams)
- [Voiceover] 10 seconds.

- You know what? This
is no big deal, guys.
Oh, is it getting colder?
- [Voiceover] I'm gonna turn it on now.

- Oh, he's turning it on now.
- [Voiceover] I'm joking.
- Is it cold yet?
- Oh, my goodness, it's so cold.

- I don't think I've ever
been this cold in my life.
- [Voiceover] Oh, my gosh.
- It's so cold.
Okay, oh my god.
- Very cool.
So now we're going into the Cryo M3,
which is the meat locker version
of the cryochamber.
- The cold happens in here, actually.
When you open this door, you get welcomed
by this big cloud of cold air.
Again, minus 220 below.
So, who's first?
(dramatic music)
(scream)
- That's a human test.
- There was something nice and comforting
about being in there.
- Oh, yes.
Oh, yeah.

Oh, I can kinda feel the
mucus in my nose crisp up.
Hello, Clarice.
That was cool. I liked that a lot.
(scream)
(laughing)
- [Voiceover] Three, two, one.
Time is up. Please exit the chamber.
- I can't speak, my brain's frozen.
There she goes.
- [Voiceover] Oh, my god!
Oh, my god!
Oh my god, oh my god, oh my god.
It's so cold.
- I think we all know who the wuss is.
- It's so cold.

- [Voiceover] This one
or the other one worse?
- I think this one.
- Usually I can't touch my toes.
Bingo, that's cryo.

Being outside in Boston
in the winter for an hour

was worse than being in there
for a minute-and-a-half.
- It was by far the coldest
that I've ever been in my entire life.

- It was definitely
invigorating and refreshing.
- I would do it again, I mean if

I see a change or feel
a really big difference
I would definitely want to come back.
So, maybe this weekend.
(techno music)

title: People Experience -220°F (-140°C) For The First Time

I'm assuming most of these people are from california and they think 50 
degrees is cold when they've never experienced 10 degree weather, which in

end well﻿
comments.author: Noelley JellyBelly

comments.text:
+John Smith
I know 10 degree weather is different than -200 degree weather, my point 
was that putting someone who is from California who thinks 50-60 degrees is 
cold into -200 degree chamber isn't going to work out as well as it would 
if the person was from somewhere like new england where having 10 degree 
cold is nothing to us
comments.author: Noelley JellyBelly

comments.text:
+Noelley JellyBelly 10 degree weather is very different then -200 degree 
weather. Average winter weather in Antarctica is about -128 degrees. So 
this is even colder then that. We are not evolved to live in such weather. 
We are also warm blooded. So yeah this is cold.

comments.text:
Why don't any of these people actually look cold when they're in the 
chambers?  No shivering at all, not scrunching up, literally no visually 
apparent physical reaction to the extreme temperatures at all.  I'm calling 
bullshit on this company and its treatment.  "I don't think I've ever been 
this cold in my life." 1:52 ~not shivering~  Also, "...minus 220 below;" oh 
the redundancy.﻿
